channel.title: Parameter change in the public dashboard doesn't work properly
channel.description:
### Issue Summary
In the public dashboards, if the user changes the global parameters, the visualization keeps showing refreshing. After refreshing the whole page or re-entering the page, the parameters work. Are there any system settings that need to be adjusted?
### Technical details:
* Redash Version: 9.0.0-beta * Browser/OS: Chrome * How did you install Redash: docker

item.title: Parameter change in the public dashboard doesn't work properly
item.dc:creator: nhkhoi
item.description:
We are having the same problem as well

Read full topic

item.description:
We’re having the same problem here - the shared dashboard does queue the job successfully with the new parameter, and query results are generated - but the client side dashboard never fetches the results, until you refresh the page.

item.description:
I’m getting the same issue. It keeps loading when I change the filters. But when I just refresh the page, the filter is applied AND loaded. The devtools show a lot of requests, but all with status 1:

job: {id: “c4ed2f20-d4e3-46db-a991-9ee1218f745a”, updated_at: 0, status: 1, error: “”, result: null,…}

Read full topic
item.source: Parameter change in the public dashboard doesn't work properly

item.title: Parameter change in the public dashboard doesn't work properly
item.dc:creator: dtian118
item.description:
@jesse I just created an AMI instance, moved all the queries and dashboards to this instance and also upgrade to V10 following the instructions.

However, for the public dashboard, the visualizations still don’t refresh after changing the global parameter. In the screenshot are the server logs and the network inspector. As you can see there actually had results back from the request, but the viz just kept showing refresh but nothing was changed.

Read full topic
item.source: Parameter change in the public dashboard doesn't work properly

item.title: Parameter change in the public dashboard doesn't work properly
item.dc:creator: jesse
item.description:
It was a mistake to run production data on the dev instance. Yikes.

Under normal circumstances, you can move from one instance to another by copying the postgres database from one machine to the other. On the AMI’s this is easy because the database files are stored in a single volume that is mapped to the host. So you copy the folder and you’re done.

With the dev instance, there is not local volume map (because it’s built for simplicity and development speed). So you need to map a volume to your postgres container, SSH into it, and copy the postgres database onto that volume. This will make the postgres data accessible from your main operating system. At which point you can FTP it onto the AMI instance.

It’s pretty complicated but this should work.

Read full topic
item.source: Parameter change in the public dashboard doesn't work properly

item.title: Parameter change in the public dashboard doesn't work properly
item.dc:creator: dtian118
item.description:
jesse:

You haven’t given enough information to know for sure.

@jesse I just terminate all the containers and start using the sudo docker-compose up, some public dashboard looks good now, but for some really large public dashboard server just restart. Looks like it run up the memory.

jesse:

It depends on where you’re migrating to and from.

From the development setup that we are currently using to the AMI instance.

Change to an AMI instance sounds like a good idea. The main concern is how to move the queries have dashboards we already have there since we already have too many things.

Read full topic
item.source: Parameter change in the public dashboard doesn't work properly

item.title: Parameter change in the public dashboard doesn't work properly
item.dc:creator: jesse
item.description:
dtian118:

Oh, so you mean run sudo docker-compose up -d would solve the public dashboard refresh issue as well?

You haven’t given enough information to know for sure.

I think you should focus on getting a functional environment before we talk about upgrading anything. Start from scratch with either a new AMI or the developer instance and see how far you get.

To your questions:

  1. yes
  2. It depends on where you’re migrating to and from.
  3. You don’t need to upgrade the development setup. You just pull the commit you want and rebuild your containers. You shouldn’t run the development setup in any kind of production environment

Read full topic
item.source: Parameter change in the public dashboard doesn't work properly

item.title: Parameter change in the public dashboard doesn't work properly
item.dc:creator: dtian118
item.description:
@jesse Oh, so you mean run sudo docker-compose up -d would solve the public dashboard refresh issue as well?
Sorry, I have 3 questions now,

  1. For the production instance setup, I think I should refer to this Setting up a Redash Instance document right?
  2. If we want to migrate the current metadata to the new instance, is there any guidebook?
  3. Is there any guidebook for upgrading the development version? Just in case we still want to keep the development version

Read full topic
item.source: Parameter change in the public dashboard doesn't work properly

item.title: Parameter change in the public dashboard doesn't work properly
item.dc:creator: jesse
item.description:
I feel like this page hasn’t been updated for a long time.

This is correct. Although there’s been no need to update it so that’s okay

I set up the ReDash follow the Docker Based Developer Installation Guide

This explains everything, including why you see 9.0.0 as your current version (see this comment from earlier today on github). I don’t see where you mentioned this before. I should have asked sooner.

Upgrading the docker development setup is completely different from a production instance. There’s no real way to do an equivalent “dry-run” upgrade since the two are so different. Because in the development environment you just check out the commit you want to run.

With all that out of the way: I think your problem is Docker doesn’t have the correct file system permissions on your copy of the code. You can try running sudo docker compose up -d instead.

A note: unless you’re familiar with development I really wouldn’t recommend running the development setup. It’s complicated and not for the faint of heart.

Read full topic
item.source: Parameter change in the public dashboard doesn't work properly

item.title: Parameter change in the public dashboard doesn't work properly
item.dc:creator: dtian118
item.description:
@jesse I checked this page before, on the page the V9 and V10 are even not on the list, and also for Step 2 in Upgrade Process, it says " Change directory to /opt/redash ", does the /opt/ means /opt on my local machine? Since I run the cd /opt/redash and it just gave me the bash: cd: /opt/redash: No such file or directory. I feel like this page hasn’t been updated for a long time.

I set up the ReDash follow the Docker Based Developer Installation Guide here, and in the docker-compose.yml file I got, there is nothing that contains the word image for redash, the image only appear under redis, Postgres and email`

For your questions, to rebuild the container I used docker-compose up --force-recreate --build -d. For the database side, I’m currently working on the ReDash in my own environment, not the one we are using now since I don’t want to take the risk. And for the containers, before each try I mentioned in the last reply, I did run the docker-compose down to ensure there is no container running.

Read full topic
item.source: Parameter change in the public dashboard doesn't work properly

item.title: Parameter change in the public dashboard doesn't work properly
item.dc:creator: jesse
item.description:
I think you’re confused about which steps to take. After upgrade you should see this version: 10.0.0 (9c928bd1)

There are upgrade instructions in our documentation.

In addition to those upgrade instructions, there are special steps when updating from V8 or earlier. However, you’re already running V9 so these wouldn’t apply to you.

The steps you followed so far

What commands did you run to rebuild the container? Did you stop and rebuild the containers? Did you run the database migrations? It sounds to me like you have a mismatch where some of your containers are running V9 and others are running V10…not good.

Read full topic
item.source: Parameter change in the public dashboard doesn't work properly

item.title: Parameter change in the public dashboard doesn't work properly
item.dc:creator: dtian118
item.description:
@jesse Upgrade instruction? Do you mean the Special instructions for upgrading from V8 or earlier?
Here are some attempts I tried so far

  1. In the V9 version, I edited the docker-compose.yml, added one more line image: redash/redash:10.0.0.b50363 above build. And then build and run the container again. However, in the web UI, it still showed the V9. But I can see the CSV in the data source, which I remember is the new feature in V10. This makes me super confused.
  2. I download the source.zip file on the release page, unzip it and run docker-compose up, then I got the error as the screenshot showed before.
  3. After I saw your last reply, I add image: redash/redash:10.0.0.b50363 in the docker-compose.yml and tried again, it still gave me the same error.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: dtian118
item.description:
Hmmm…I just had a quick try. Like on the ReDash dashboard page I set my parameter to a certain value and it works properly as usual, and then on the public dashboard I put the exact same parameter, the viz still loads forever…Probably need to upgrade to V10 as you mentioned it has better support. Can you show me a tutorial about upgrading? We already have many queries and dashboards there, just afraid of losing some data.

item.source: Parameter change in the public dashboard doesn't work properly

item.title: Parameter change in the public dashboard doesn't work properly
item.dc:creator: jesse
item.description:
Pretty much. This was improved in V10 somewhat so that all but text parameters are considered safe. But overall this isn’t a use-case we support very well. If you want people to execute queries they need to be logged-in. Redash isn’t built for embedded analytics.

Read full topic
item.source: Parameter change in the public dashboard doesn't work properly

item.title: Parameter change in the public dashboard doesn't work properly
item.dc:creator: dtian118
item.description:
So you mean if users want to play with the parameters on the public dashboard, we have to play with all the parameters on the ReDash dashboard page first to make some cache there. And then when they change parameters on the public dashboard the viz will load properly since it can fetch the cache in metadata db. Am I right?

Read full topic
item.source: Parameter change in the public dashboard doesn't work properly

item.title: Parameter change in the public dashboard doesn't work properly
item.dc:creator: jesse
item.description:
To be clear, public dashboards cannot refresh queries. All they do is fetch the latest cached result from the metadata db.

Read full topic
